newsitem.title: FRANCE: GAN bail-out bill could overshoot -paper.
newsitem.headline: GAN bail-out bill could overshoot -paper.

text.p: The French government's rescue of state-owned insurer Groupe des Assurances Nationales (GAN) could cost 10 billion francs ($1.8 billion) more than the 20 billion francs which has been earmarked, according to GAN's former chairman, the British daily Financial Times said on Monday.

The government plan puts the bill at 20 billion francs -- a capital injection of 11 billion and nine billion for estimated losses on property asset sales -- but the precise cost of the overhaul will only be known once property sales are completed.
The newspaper said "an official close to the discussions over the rescue" had acknowledged that the total bill could be as high as 25 billion, but equally come in as low as 15 billion.
The finance ministry declined to comment beyond saying none of its officials had made comments on a possible overshoot.
The government announced the rescue on February 27, saying the group had ran up losses of 35 billion since 1992, mainly because of troubles at its UIC property unit.
It hopes to immunise the insurance arm and CIC banking subsidiary from UIC and privatise those two businesses "during the course of 1997", according the Finance Minister Jean Arthuis.
